data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An aromatic gum resin obtained from several trees and shrubs of the genus Commiphora of northeastern Africa and Arabia, used in perfume, incense, and medicinal preparations.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A gummy resinous exudation from several species of Commiphora (Balsamodendron).
The sweet cicely of Europe. See <internalXref urlencoded="Myrrhis">Myrrhis</internalXref>.

A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of an aromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste. It is valued for its odor and for its medicinal properties. It exudes from the bark of a shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the <spn>Commiphora Myrrha</spn> (syn. <spn>Balsamodendron Myrrha</spn>) of the family <ex>Burseraceae</ex>, or from the <spn>Commiphora abyssinica</spn>. The myrrh of the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, and partly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose.

from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A red-brown <xref>resinous</xref> material, the dried sap of the Commiphora <xref>myrrha</xref> tree.

data.text: aromatic resin that is burned as incense and used in perfume
